title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO — History arrived in Chicago not with a whisper, but with the thunderous, relentless force of Karl Malone’s right hand. On a night where championship aspirations hung in the balance, the Utah Jazz rode the broad shoulders of their MVP to a pivotal 101-94 victory over the Chicago Bulls, powered by one of the most dominant individual performances in Finals history.

Malone was simply unstoppable, pouring in a Herculean 39 points while snatching 9 rebounds. Every crucial possession ran through the "Mailman," and he delivered time and again, bullying his way to the basket with a combination of brute strength and flawless footwork. The Bulls threw multiple defenders his way, but on this night, there was no answer.

While Malone’s scoring was the headline, John Stockton was the master conductor, dishing out 12 assists and orchestrating the offense with surgical precision. Jeff Hornacek provided vital support with 15 points, stretching the Chicago defense.

The Bulls, fighting to protect their home court, were led by Michael Jordan's 29 points and Scottie Pippen's 18. But even their legendary efforts paled against the Malone onslaught. Every Chicago run was met with a Malone post-up, a Malone turnaround, or a Malone trip to the free-throw line.

In the end, this was not merely a win; it was a statement. A declaration that Utah’s heart beat through Karl Malone. By placing the entire offensive burden on his back and watching him carry them to victory, the Jazz seized control of The Finals and cemented a performance for the ages.
